NO NO! ERROR: At 1:09 ... There is no such thing as 'Zero Gravity'. People confuse weightlessness and 'zero gravity' up. But they are very different. Gravity permeates every single corner of the Universe. Because gravity is the manifestation of any and all matter. Matter's existence creates gravity. You don't notice your own gravity or the gravity from, say, Mt. Everest, because in relation to the gigantic Earth, it's too insignificant to notice. But gravity doesn't magically go away. People think astronauts floating in a spacecraft are not experiencing gravity. Wrong. They're in orbit. So they feel 'weightlessness'. It counters the gravitational force of Earth, but only because such astronauts are also hurtling sideways at fantastic speeds (technically called 'escape velocity', or over 17,000 mph) or around the Earth.
You know gravity is always present because you can see the Moon. It's Earth's companion because it's stuck within Earth's gravity well, if you will. The Sun, Mars, Venus, the other planets and stars... they're all in their own orbits, too. And it's all because of GRAVITY.

That said, the further one gets from Earth's center of mass, the less their gravitational bond will be. But astronauts in Space never are far enough away from Earth to truly escape Earth's gravity. For Example: Last week when William Shatner went into 'Space', he was only above an arbitrary line we define as 'Space'. But it was barely 60 miles up. At that distance, you're still feeling 96% of the Earth's gravity.

FLAMES IN SPACE: So... A flame in space would not have a circular plume. It would be pointing toward Earth or whatever large celestial body it's nearest. For a flame to have a circular plume it would have to be in ORBIT. And that's where all flames in space were filmed: They were all shown while an astronaut was in a spacecraft orbiting Earth. If the flame was alone and not in orbit, and lit, it would have the same plume we see on Earth's surface, except instead of pointing up, the flame would point down. Down toward Earth's huge gravitational mass.

The visible part of fire that you see is Black Body Radiation. Black body radiation is the conversion of Thermal Energy to Electromagnetic Energy (essentially light).
When things heat up (which is generally started by friction), the molecules in the material move faster, and this corresponds to temperature. More movement = more heat. The molecules undergo acceleration and emit Electromagnetic Radiation (Light). This is why when things get hot, they glow, red being the lowest visable color on the electromagnetic spectrum, thus less energy and less heat, blue/violet being higher energy and hotter flames.

Anti-ferromagnetism and ferromagnetism are exactly the same as diamagnetism/paramagnetism except there isn't enough heat/vibration energy for the molecules to disalign. A molecule will exert a force on a nearby molecule. That's why tapping/heating magnets demagnetises them. Some things you can cool down to become permanent magnets, like gadolinium. For others not enough of their molecules align in an external magnetic field to form a self-sustaining field against heat/vibration.

I'm assuming you got my last post. Nope, not finished yet. Diamagnetism and paramagnetism is due to the shape of molecules. Electrons align themselves with the field. But the shape of diamagnetic molecules means the opposite end is closest. Paramagnetism the opposite happens. A field can induce poles by directly affecting the electrons, like in non-bonded atoms like neon. Heat (mini-vibration) and vibration cause them to face random directions.

One that's greater, that is. "non-polar" molecules actually have poles, just not ones that are greater than each other. For example, BF3. The poles everywhere (where there are more/less electrons, which are negative) mean lots of things are magnetic. Water, for example. The different types of poles are what cause some to be paramagnetic (temporarily attracted by an external magnetic field) and some to be diamagnetic (temporarily repelled by an external magnetic field).

Ionic bonds happen when an atom attracts an electron more than another atom due to electronegativity: the difference in charge and the distance. Covalent bonds just happen when neither is strong enough. When two are just as strong as each other the obvious happens. Like H2. When one is stronger, just not strong enough to completely pull away an electron, the electron simply orbits it the stronger atom more than the other, causing it to be polar. Like H2O. Polar meaning an overall pole.

If you think about it, vibrations aren't exactly good for molecular bonds. That's why heat causes bonds to break. Metallic bonds are when positive ions share delocalised electrons. They happen when (the outermost) electrons are far away enough from the nucleus to break free. Ionic, when an atom gives one or more electrons to another, causing them to be ions. Oppositely charged things attract. Covalent, when two atoms share electrons. Heat would just cause the nuclei to move away from each other.

Oh, I forgot. By charged particles I mean electrons. Photons can energise electrons, causing them to have enough energy to escape an atom. Likewise, electrons can encounter and release a photon, causing them to de-energise and orbit an atom. That's how solar panels and light bulbs work. Everything does this, it's just that solar panels and light bulbs are much more efficient. Ever wonder why hot things feel hot even when there's no steam? Heat is just kinetic energy on a small scale.

So... the intrinsical force that makes the less dense liquid to move upward is its own electromagnetism. What happens if it's used up? Does the less dense fluid stay below the more dense one?

Fundamentally, this is due to tiny collisions of the fluid with the surface of the cube. Even more fundamentally, these collisions are possible due to electromagnetism. I feel in order to understand this much better, you need to mathematically derive this but there is quite a good Wikipedia page that explains it much better.

Anyway, to simply answer your question, it is possible for an "undense" (less dense) fluid to move against gravity because of this effect called Buoyancy.

The same thing occurs with Buoyancy. When an object is immersed in a fluid, the fluid will exert an upwards force on the object. This upwards force is due to the resultant pressure of the fluid acting on the object (the reason we have this resultant pressure/force is because of gravity and it can mathematically be shown the weight of the fluid displaced = the weight of the object immersed when in equilibrium). (Read next post).

It depends on what you mean by intrinsic; for example, when you stand on Earth, gravity is pulling you downwards. I.e. The force of gravity is acting downwards. So why don't you continue falling towards the centre of the Earth? Well, because an opposing force is acting against you which is referred to as the "Reaction" force. Intrinsically, the force acting against gravity is  electrostatic force (i.e. electromagnetism). (Read second post for further explanation)

Yes we would :) Although, biologically, we wouldn't survive very long. You can estimate how hot we need to be using something called Wien's displacement law. It states Wavelength * Temperature (In kelvin) = 2.8977685(51)×10−3 m·K. The wavelength of visible light is around 10^-6 metres. Thus in Kevin, out temperature would need to be around 2897 K which is around 2600 degrees Celsius! Hot :)

Imagine I have a perfect circle and measure the perimeter of that circle (called the circumference, i.e. the length going around the circle). I then measure the distance from one end of the circle to the other end of the circle (the end furthest away, called the diameter). "Pi" is always equal to the ratio of the perimeter of the circle and its diameter i.e. Pi = Perimeter / Diameter. This value, Pi, always equals 3.14159265359... it goes on forever.
What you see as fire isn't "matter" and thus isn't solid, liquid or gas. The "colours" you see are simply photons being emitted by hot molecules/atoms due to thermal radiation.

This is what Buoyancy is about. You are correct in saying that the gravitational field produced by the Earth acts towards its centre of mass, but if you have two 'fluids' placed on top of each other, the denser fluid will always float to the bottom while the less dense fluid will rise to the top due pressure differences. This is what is happening here. If you look up "Buoyancy" on Wikipedia, it explains it quite well.

When the oxygen combines with the carbons, much energy is released. This surplus of energy heats particles of carbon (soot) and other things like ash in the flame, causing it to glow and give off energy as radiation. The air around the flame is heated, which on our planet causes the hot air to rise, pulling in cooler air into the bottom, feeding in fresh oxygen to the flame.
I hope this gives you a better idea of what's chemically going on in a flame. :)

The long chains of carbons break apart and the carbon atoms combine with oxygen. If the flame is hot enough, each carbon gets two oxygens attached, forming CO2 (carbon dioxide). If it's not hot enough for complete burning, then CO is formed (carbon monoxide) a deadly poison (in concentration). Along with the CO or CO2, the hydrogens from the hydrocarbon chains match up with oxygens, forming H2O, or plain water. Sometimes there are chains of carbons which don't burn, and these are soot.

The wax keeps the wick cool so it doesn't burn away too quickly.
But to your question, what's happening at the atomic level? The heat of the fire boils some of the wax molecules, which are long-chain hydrocarbons, similar to gasoline or plastic. This vaporized wax acts as the fuel for the flame, and combines with oxygen from the air. When the hydrocarbon chain combines with oxygen, each oxygen molecule (O2) breaks apart into two separate oxygens, and the oxygens attack carbons from the wax.

Dara, fire is what we call the process of oxidation, when it happens in an energetic manner that's self-sustaining. Let's take a candle as an example.
The wick of the candle is made of string, and the string is good at absorbing some wax. When you light the wick with a match or a lighter, you heat it up until it starts burning. The heat from the lighter, then from the wick melts some of the wax at the top of the candle, which then is sucked up the wick by capillary action. [continued]
